choices.text: The external nose is entirely cartilaginous and contains only septal cartilage
The upper one-third of the external nose is bony, formed by the paired nasal bones
The lower one-third of the external nose is formed by nasal bones and vomer
The cartilaginous part includes only the upper lateral and alar cartilages

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the composition of the external nose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The upper one-third of the external nose is bony, formed by the paired nasal bones

 

The upper one-third of the external nose is bony, formed by paired nasal bones. This is a defining structural feature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The external nose is entirely cartilaginous and contains only septal cartilage: Incorrect. The external nose has both bony and cartilaginous components. It is not entirely cartilaginous.

 

Option C. The lower one-third of the external nose is formed by nasal bones and vomer: Incorrect. The lower two-thirds is cartilaginous, not formed by nasal bones or vomer (vomer is part of nasal septum, not external nose).

 

Option D. The cartilaginous part includes only the upper lateral and alar cartilages: Incorrect. The cartilaginous part of the external nose includes upper lateral cartilages, lower lateral (alar) cartilages, lesser alar/sesamoid cartilages, and septal cartilage, not just the upper lateral and alar ones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The external nose is made up of an upper bony one-third (paired nasal bones) and a lower two-thirds cartilaginous part (including upper lateral, lower lateral/alar, lesser alar, and septal cartilages).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 134

choices.text: Nasal basal cell carcinoma
Rhinophyma
Sebaceous cyst of the nose
Nasal vestibulitis

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with progressive thickening and enlargement of the tip of his nose over the past several years. He has a long-standing history of acne rosacea. On examination, his nasal tip appears bulbous, lobulated, and red with prominent pores. There are no signs of active infection or systemic symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinophyma

 

This is a late complication of acne rosacea characterized by sebaceous gland hypertrophy predominantly affecting the thick skin overlying the alar cartilages. Clinically presents as a bulbous, red, lobulated nose. It is sometimes referred to as "potato tumor."

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal basal cell carcinoma: While basal cell carcinoma can affect the nose and may present with ulceration, bleeding, or a pearly nodule, it does not cause diffuse lobular hypertrophy of the nasal tip as seen here.

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst of the nose: Typically presents as a localized, soft, fluctuant swelling. It does not cause diffuse nasal tip thickening or the lobulated appearance seen in rhinophyma.

 

Option D. Nasal vestibulitis: This condition presents with tenderness, redness, and crusting in the anterior nares and vestibule due to Staph aureus infection. It is acute and painful, unlike the chronic, non-tender hypertrophy in rhinophyma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinophyma is a complication of acne rosacea caused by sebaceous gland hypertrophy, presenting as a bulbous, lobulated enlargement of the nasal tip, typically managed by laser or surgical excision.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 134

choices.text: The nasal vestibule is lined by respiratory epithelium
Furuncles of the vestibule are most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes
The vestibule contains sebaceous glands and vibrissae with hair follicles
The vestibule is supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the nasal vestibule is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The vestibule contains sebaceous glands and vibrissae with hair follicles

 

The vestibule is the skin-lined entry part of the nasal cavity, and it contains sebaceous glands and vibrissae (nasal hairs). Infections of these hair follicles by Staphylococcus can lead to furuncles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The nasal vestibule is lined by respiratory epithelium: Incorrect. The nasal vestibule is lined by skin, not respiratory epithelium. It has epidermal features like hair and sebaceous glands. Respiratory epithelium lines the more posterior nasal cavity.

 

Option B. Furuncles of the vestibule are most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes: Incorrect. Furuncles (boils) of the vestibule are commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, not Streptococcus pyogenes. These infections can be serious due to the danger triangle of the face.

 

Option D. The vestibule is supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerve: Incorrect. The infraorbital nerve (branch of maxillary nerve - V2) supplies the nasal vestibule. The anterior ethmoidal nerve (branch of nasociliary nerve - V1) supplies the anterior superior part of the nasal cavity, not the vestibule.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The nasal vestibule is skin-lined and contains sebaceous glands and vibrissae; it is innervated by infraorbital nerve branches and is a common site for Staphylococcus-induced furuncles.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 135

choices.text: The nasal valve is the widest part of the nasal cavity and aids in olfaction
Its lateral boundary is formed by the lower lateral (alar) cartilage
The angle formed between the septum and upper lateral cartilage is approximately 15 degrees
It is bounded medially by the inferior turbinate and laterally by the middle turbinate

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the nasal valve is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The angle formed between the septum and upper lateral cartilage is approximately 15 degrees

 

The angle between the nasal septum medially and the upper lateral cartilage laterally/superiorly is approximately 10-15 degrees—this defines the narrow airflow channel of the nasal valve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The nasal valve is the widest part of the nasal cavity and aids in olfaction: Incorrect. The nasal valve is the narrowest (not widest) part of the nasal cavity and plays a crucial role in airflow resistance, not olfaction.

 

Option B. Its lateral boundary is formed by the lower lateral (alar) cartilage: Incorrect. The lateral boundary of the nasal valve is formed by the lower border of the upper lateral cartilage, not the lower lateral (alar) cartilage.

 

Option D. It is bounded medially by the inferior turbinate and laterally by the middle turbinate: Incorrect. The nasal valve is located anteriorly, and its boundaries do not include turbinates. The inferior and middle turbinates are part of the deeper nasal cavity and are not involved in forming the nasal valve.

 

Educational Objective:


The nasal valve is the narrowest part of the nasal cavity, formed by the septum medially, floor inferiorly, and lower edge of the upper lateral cartilage laterally, with an angle of ~10-15° between septum and cartilage.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 135

choices.text: It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies within the middle meatus
Its mucosa contains vascular channels running anterior to posterior
It attaches anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone
It plays no role in humidifying inspired air

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the inferior turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It attaches anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone

 

The inferior turbinate is a separate bone that is attached anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone. It also connects to the lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies within the middle meatus: Incorrect. The inferior turbinate is a separate bone, unlike the superior and middle turbinates, which are part of the ethmoid bone. Also, it lies in the inferior meatus, not middle.

 

Option B. Its mucosa contains vascular channels running anterior to posterior: Incorrect. The vascular channels in the mucosa run from posterior to anterior, not anterior to posterior. This orientation helps maintain long contact with inspired air for effective humidification.

 

Option D. It plays no role in humidifying inspired air: Incorrect. The inferior turbinate plays a significant role in humidifying inspired air due to its vascular mucosa, which helps condition the air before it reaches the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:


The inferior turbinate is a separate bone attached to the maxilla and palatine bone, with posterior-to-anterior vascular channels in its mucosa aiding in humidification of inspired air.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 135

choices.text: The nasolacrimal duct opens into the middle meatus, guarded by the valve of Hasner
The lacrimal sac lies lateral to the medial canthus and connects directly to the inferior turbinate
Blinking activates the lacrimal pump mechanism via compression of the lacrimal canaliculi
Tear secretions are directly drained into the nasal vestibule during crying

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the drainage of lacrimal secretions is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blinking activates the lacrimal pump mechanism via compression of the lacrimal canaliculi

 

Blinking causes contraction of the medial canthal ligament, which compresses the lacrimal canaliculi, pushing tear secretions into the lacrimal sac — this is known as the lacrimal pump mechanism.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the middle meatus, guarded by the valve of Hasner: Incorrect. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus, not the middle meatus. It is guarded by the valve of Hasner at its nasal end.

 

Option B. The lacrimal sac lies lateral to the medial canthus and connects directly to the inferior turbinate: Incorrect. The lacrimal sac lies medial to the medial canthus, not lateral, and it drains into the nasolacrimal duct, which then opens into the inferior meatus, not directly onto the turbinate.

 

 

Option D. Tear secretions are directly drained into the nasal vestibule during crying: Incorrect. Tear secretions drain into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity, not into the nasal vestibule. The moistening of the nose during crying is due to this connection.

 

Educational Objective:


Tear secretions drain from the lacrimal sac into the inferior meatus via the nasolacrimal duct, aided by blinking-induced lacrimal pump action compressing the canaliculi.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 135

choices.text: The second part of the middle turbinate lies in the sagittal plane and attaches to the cribriform plate
The ground lamella (basal lamella) separates the superior and middle meatus
The third part of the middle turbinate runs horizontally toward the posterior choana and attaches to the lamina papyracea
The agger nasi lies behind the middle turbinate attachment and is never pneumatized

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the middle turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The third part of the middle turbinate runs horizontally toward the posterior choana and attaches to the lamina papyracea

 

The third part of the middle turbinate lies in the axial plane, runs horizontally toward the posterior choana, and attaches to the lamina papyracea — this is the correct anatomical description.

 

 

 

Scan this QR code for video demonstration of nasal endoscopic anatomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The second part of the middle turbinate lies in the sagittal plane and attaches to the cribriform plate: Incorrect. The first part of the middle turbinate lies in the sagittal plane and attaches to the cribriform plate. The second part, not the first, lies in the coronal plane.

 

Option B. The ground lamella (basal lamella) separates the superior and middle meatus: Incorrect. The ground lamella (or basal lamella, which is the second part) separates the anterior and posterior ethmoid cells, not the superior and middle meatus.

 

Option D. The agger nasi lies behind the middle turbinate attachment and is never pneumatized: Incorrect. The agger nasi lies anterosuperior to the middle turbinate attachment (not behind it), and is often pneumatized, forming an air cell in most individuals.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The third (axial) part of the middle turbinate runs horizontally toward the posterior choana and attaches to the lamina papyracea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 136

choices.text: The uncinate process lies posterior to the ethmoidal bulla and opens directly into the suprabullar recess
The space between the uncinate process and ethmoidal bulla is called the infundibulum
The natural ostium of the maxillary sinus opens into the infundibulum in the middle meatus
Haller cells are located between the ethmoidal bulla and uncinate process within the hiatus semilunaris

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the middle meatus is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The natural ostium of the maxillary sinus opens into the infundibulum in the middle meatus

 

The natural ostium of the maxillary sinus opens into the infundibulum, which lies in the middle meatus. This is a key feature of the osteomeatal complex.

 

 

 

 

Scan this QR code for video demonstration of nasal endoscopic anatomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The uncinate process lies posterior to the ethmoidal bulla and opens directly into the suprabullar recess: Incorrect. The uncinate process lies anterior to the ethmoidal bulla, and the hiatus semilunaris lies between them. The suprabullar recess lies above the bulla, not connected directly to the uncinate process.

 

Option B. The space between the uncinate process and ethmoidal bulla is called the infundibulum: Incorrect. The space between the uncinate process and ethmoidal bulla is the hiatus semilunaris (a 2D cleft). The infundibulum is the 3D space into which this cleft opens.

 

Option D. Haller cells are located between the ethmoidal bulla and uncinate process within the hiatus semilunaris: Incorrect. Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells, formed by pneumatization of the roof of the maxillary sinus (orbital floor), not located in the hiatus semilunaris.

 

Educational Objective:


The natural ostium of the maxillary sinus opens into the infundibulum, a key space in the middle meatus that forms part of the osteomeatal unit.

 

Ref: PL Dhingra, 6th Ed.; Radiological and endoscopic sinus anatomy references.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 136

choices.text: Uncinate attached to lamina papyracea → Frontal sinus drains laterally into maxillary sinus
Uncinate attached to skull base → Frontal sinus drains medially into nasal cavity
Uncinate attached to middle turbinate → Frontal sinus drains laterally into infundibulum/maxillary sinus
Uncinate attached laterally to lamina papyracea → Frontal sinus drains laterally into maxillary sinus

questions.text: A surgeon performing Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is evaluating the uncinate process attachment to determine the drainage pathway of the frontal sinus. Which of the following attachment patterns of the uncinate process is correctly matched with the corresponding drainage route of the frontal sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uncinate attached to middle turbinate → Frontal sinus drains laterally into infundibulum/maxillary sinus

 

When the uncinate is attached medially to the middle turbinate, the frontal sinus drainage is directed laterally into the infundibulum, which may lead to the maxillary sinus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncinate attached to lamina papyracea → Frontal sinus drains laterally into maxillary sinus: Incorrect. If the uncinate is attached laterally to the lamina papyracea, the frontal sinus drains medially into the nasal cavity—not laterally.

 

Option B. Uncinate attached to skull base → Frontal sinus drains medially into nasal cavity: Incorrect. If the uncinate attaches superiorly to the skull base, the frontal sinus drains laterally into the infundibulum, not medially.

 

Option D. Uncinate attached laterally to lamina papyracea → Frontal sinus drains laterally into maxillary sinus: Incorrect. As explained in A, lateral attachment to lamina papyracea redirects the frontal drainage medially, not laterally.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Frontal sinus drainage depends on the site of uncinate process attachment; medial attachment to middle turbinate directs drainage laterally into the maxillary sinus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 137

choices.text: The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that may lie close to the optic nerve
Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess
The superior turbinate is a separate bone that marks the opening of the frontal sinus
The sphenoid sinus opens into the superior meatus, lateral to the middle turbinate

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy around the superior turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that may lie close to the optic nerve

 

The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that may pneumatize near or even over the optic nerve, making it clinically significant during sinus surgery. Mnemonic: OO = Onodi–Optic.

 

 

Arrow marked structures are onodi cells and star shaped structures are sphenoid sinuses

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess: Incorrect. Posterior ethmoidal air cells open into the superior meatus, not the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

 

Option C. The superior turbinate is a separate bone that marks the opening of the frontal sinus: Incorrect. The superior turbinate is part of the ethmoid bone, not a separate bone, and it marks the sphenoid ostium, not the frontal sinus opening.

 

 

Option D. The sphenoid sinus opens into the superior meatus, lateral to the middle turbinate: Incorrect. The sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is above and medial to the superior turbinate, not into the superior meatus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that lies close to the optic nerve and is important to identify during endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 137

choices.text: The olfactory nerve supplies the posterior part of the lateral nasal wall
The sphenopalatine ganglion lies anterior to the middle turbinate in the nasal cavity
The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the anterior and superior part of the lateral nasal wall
Branches of the greater palatine nerve supply the superior portion of the lateral nasal wall

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the nerve supply of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the anterior and superior part of the lateral nasal wall

 

The anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from V1), supplies the anterior and superior part of the lateral nasal wall.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The olfactory nerve supplies the posterior part of the lateral nasal wall: Incorrect. The olfactory nerve (CN I) is responsible for smell and is located superiorly on the cribriform plate, not for general sensory innervation of the posterior lateral wall.

 

Option B. The sphenopalatine ganglion lies anterior to the middle turbinate in the nasal cavity: Incorrect. The sphenopalatine ganglion lies in the pterygopalatine fossa, which is accessed posterior to the middle turbinate via the sphenopalatine foramen, approximately 1 cm posterior to the turbinate’s posterior end.

 

Option D. Branches of the greater palatine nerve supply the superior portion of the lateral nasal wall: Incorrect. The greater palatine nerve supplies the hard palate, not the superior portion of the lateral nasal wall.

 

Educational Objective:


The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the anterior and superior part of the lateral nasal wall, while posterior parts are innervated by branches from the sphenopalatine ganglion.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: The bulla ethmoidalis lies anterior to the uncinate process and forms the anterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris
The space above or behind the bulla ethmoidalis is called the infundibulum
The bulla ethmoidalis can fuse posteriorly with the ground lamella and may extend superiorly to the skull base
The hiatus semilunaris superior lies between the uncinate process and the lamina papyracea

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the bulla ethmoidalis and its anatomical relations is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The bulla ethmoidalis can fuse posteriorly with the ground lamella and may extend superiorly to the skull base

 

The bulla ethmoidalis, depending on its pneumatization, may extend superiorly to the skull base and fuse posteriorly with the ground (basal) lamella, which separates anterior and posterior ethmoid cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The bulla ethmoidalis lies anterior to the uncinate process and forms the anterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris: Incorrect. The bulla ethmoidalis lies behind the uncinate process, not in front. It forms the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris inferior, not the anterior boundary.

 

Option B. The space above or behind the bulla ethmoidalis is called the infundibulum: Incorrect. The space above or behind the bulla is called the suprabullar or retrobullar recess, not the infundibulum. The infundibulum is the space into which the hiatus semilunaris inferior opens.

 

 

Option D. The hiatus semilunaris superior lies between the uncinate process and the lamina papyracea: Incorrect. The hiatus semilunaris superior is a cleft-like communication between the bulla and skull base, not between the uncinate and lamina papyracea.

 

Educational Objective:


The bulla ethmoidalis lies posterior to the uncinate process, may extend to the skull base, and can fuse with the ground lamella, forming part of the lateral sinus anatomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: The agger nasi lies posterior to the middle turbinate and contains the bulla ethmoidalis
An enlarged agger nasi cell may obstruct the maxillary sinus ostium
The agger nasi is an elevation anterior to the middle turbinate and may contain air cells communicating with the frontal recess
The agger nasi communicates directly with the sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Agger nasi is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The agger nasi is an elevation anterior to the middle turbinate and may contain air cells communicating with the frontal recess

 

The agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the middle turbinate attachment, and when pneumatized, it forms agger nasi cells that typically communicate with the frontal recess. Enlargement can lead to mechanical obstruction of frontal sinus drainage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The agger nasi lies posterior to the middle turbinate and contains the bulla ethmoidalis: Incorrect. The agger nasi lies anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate, not posterior. The bulla ethmoidalis is a separate structure located more posteriorly.

 

Option B. An enlarged agger nasi cell may obstruct the maxillary sinus ostium: Incorrect. Enlargement of the agger nasi cell affects the frontal recess, not the maxillary sinus ostium. Obstruction in this region can impact frontal sinus drainage.

 

Opiton D. The agger nasi communicates directly with the sphenoethmoidal recess: Incorrect. The sphenoethmoidal recess is located posterior and superior, near the superior turbinate, and has no direct communication with the agger nasi.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The agger nasi lies anterior to the middle turbinate, may be pneumatized, and communicates with the frontal recess, potentially obstructing frontal sinus drainage if enlarged.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: Concha bullosa is a pneumatized inferior turbinate that drains into the maxillary sinus
Pneumatization of the middle turbinate resulting in concha bullosa may drain into the frontal recess
Concha bullosa refers to a cystic lesion of the middle meatus with no communication to sinuses
Concha bullosa is an abnormality of the superior turbinate and communicates with the sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding concha bullosa is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatization of the middle turbinate resulting in concha bullosa may drain into the frontal recess

 

Concha bullosa results from pneumatization of the middle turbinate, leading to a ballooned-out appearance. It can drain directly into the frontal recess or through agger nasi cells, potentially affecting frontal sinus drainage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized inferior turbinate that drains into the maxillary sinus: Incorrect. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate, not the inferior turbinate. The inferior turbinate is rarely pneumatized.

 

Option C. Concha bullosa refers to a cystic lesion of the middle meatus with no communication to sinuses: Incorrect. Concha bullosa is not a cystic lesion; it is an aerated (air-filled) cavity within the middle turbinate, often communicating with the frontal recess system.

 

Option D. Concha bullosa is an abnormality of the superior turbinate and communicates with the sphenoid sinus: Incorrect. Concha bullosa involves the middle turbinate, not the superior turbinate, and it does not communicate with the sphenoid sinus, which opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:


Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate that may drain into the frontal recess directly or via agger nasi cells, affecting frontal sinus drainage.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: Haller cells are air cells located in the floor of the nasal cavity and derived from sphenoid sinus
Haller cells arise from anterior or posterior ethmoid cells and are located in the roof of the maxillary sinus
Haller cells communicate with the frontal sinus and may cause frontal sinus obstruction
Haller cells are located in the lamina papyracea and commonly obstruct the sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Haller cells is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Haller cells arise from anterior or posterior ethmoid cells and are located in the roof of the maxillary sinus

 

Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells situated in the roof of the maxillary sinus and are pneumatized extensions from anterior or posterior ethmoid air cells. If enlarged, they can encroach on the ethmoid infundibulum, interfering with maxillary sinus drainage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haller cells are air cells located in the floor of the nasal cavity and derived from sphenoid sinus: Incorrect. Haller cells are not located in the floor of the nasal cavity nor are they derived from the sphenoid sinus. They are related to ethmoid cells.

 

Option C. Haller cells communicate with the frontal sinus and may cause frontal sinus obstruction: Incorrect. Haller cells are not involved in frontal sinus drainage; they impact the maxillary sinus drainage pathway via obstruction of the infundibulum.

 

Option D. Haller cells are located in the lamina papyracea and commonly obstruct the sphenoethmoidal recess: Incorrect. While Haller cells are located near the orbital floor (infraorbital), they are not typically in the lamina papyracea, and they do not obstruct the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is related to the sphenoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:


Haller cells are infraorbital air cells derived from anterior or posterior ethmoidal cells, located in the roof of the maxillary sinus and may obstruct its drainage by encroaching on the infundibulum.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: The superior turbinate is part of the maxillary bone and is located anterior to the middle turbinate
The superior turbinate lies lateral to the sphenoid sinus ostium and is derived from the frontal bone
The superior turbinate is the main drainage site for the anterior ethmoid and maxillary sinuses
The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal, located posterior and superior to the middle turbinate, and serves as a key landmark for identifying the sphenoid sinus ostium

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the superior turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal, located posterior and superior to the middle turbinate, and serves as a key landmark for identifying the sphenoid sinus ostium

 

The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal, located posterior and superior to the middle turbinate, and is a reliable endoscopic landmark to locate the sphenoid sinus ostium, which lies medial to it.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The superior turbinate is part of the maxillary bone and is located anterior to the middle turbinate: Incorrect. The superior turbinate is not derived from the maxillary bone and is not located anterior to the middle turbinate. It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies posterior and superior.

 

Option B. The superior turbinate lies lateral to the sphenoid sinus ostium and is derived from the frontal bone: Incorrect. The sphenoid ostium lies medial, not lateral, to the superior turbinate. The turbinate itself is not derived from the frontal bone.

 

Option C. The superior turbinate is the main drainage site for the anterior ethmoid and maxillary sinuses: Incorrect. The superior turbinate is not involved in drainage of anterior ethmoid or maxillary sinuses. These drain into the middle meatus, not near the superior turbinate.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The superior turbinate is an ethmoturbinal that lies posterior and superior to the middle turbinate and helps identify the sphenoid sinus ostium located medial to it.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: The superior meatus lies above the superior turbinate and receives drainage from the frontal sinus
The superior meatus is located below the superior turbinate and receives drainage from posterior ethmoid cells
The superior meatus lies below the middle turbinate and drains the maxillary sinus
The superior meatus receives drainage from the sphenoid sinus via the sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the superior meatus is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The superior meatus is located below the superior turbinate and receives drainage from posterior ethmoid cells

 

The superior meatus is the space beneath the superior turbinate, and it is the drainage site for the posterior ethmoid air cells, which can vary in number from 1 to 5.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The superior meatus lies above the superior turbinate and receives drainage from the frontal sinus: Incorrect. The superior meatus lies below the superior turbinate, not above it, and it does not receive drainage from the frontal sinus. The frontal sinus drains into the frontal recess, which is part of the middle meatus region.

 

Option C. The superior meatus lies below the middle turbinate and drains the maxillary sinus: Incorrect. The middle meatus, not the superior meatus, lies below the middle turbinate and receives drainage from the maxillary sinus via the infundibulum.

 

Option D. The superior meatus receives drainage from the sphenoid sinus via the sphenoethmoidal recess: Incorrect. The sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which lies superior and medial to the superior turbinate, not into the superior meatus.

 

Educational Objective:


The superior meatus lies below the superior turbinate and receives drainage from the posterior ethmoid cells, which typically number between 1 to 5.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: Onodi cell is an anterior ethmoid air cell that communicates with the frontal sinus
Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoid cell that may extend superior or lateral to the sphenoid sinus and lie close to the optic nerve
Onodi cell lies in the floor of the maxillary sinus and is related to the infraorbital nerve
Onodi cell drains into the inferior meatus and has no surgical significance

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Onodi cell is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoid cell that may extend superior or lateral to the sphenoid sinus and lie close to the optic nerve

 

The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that may extend superior or lateral to the sphenoid sinus—sometimes up to 1.5 cm from the anterior wall of the sphenoid. It is surgically important because the optic nerve may lie in close relation to its lateral wall, posing a risk during sinus surgery.

 

STAR – SPHENOID SINUS, ARROW – ONODI CELL

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Onodi cell is an anterior ethmoid air cell that communicates with the frontal sinus: Incorrect. The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoid cell, not an anterior one, and it does not communicate with the frontal sinus. It extends posteriorly near the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Onodi cell lies in the floor of the maxillary sinus and is related to the infraorbital nerve: Incorrect. The Onodi cell is not found in the floor of the maxillary sinus and has no relation to the infraorbital nerve. That description fits Haller cells.

 

Option D. Onodi cell drains into the inferior meatus and has no surgical significance: Incorrect. The Onodi cell does not drain into the inferior meatus. It is surgically significant, especially in endoscopic sinus surgery, due to its proximity to the optic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoid air cell that may extend near or above the sphenoid sinus and is important surgically due to its close relation to the optic nerve.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: It is located in the middle meatus, anterior to the ethmoidal bulla and posterior to the uncinate process
It lies within the superior meatus, between the middle turbinate and the roof of the nasal cavity
It opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, medial to the superior turbinate, about 1 cm above the posterior choana
It is found lateral to the middle turbinate, at the level of the agger nasi cells and frontal recess

questions.text: During endoscopic sinus surgery, a surgeon is attempting to locate the ostium of the sphenoid sinus. Which of the following anatomical descriptions most accurately guides this identification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, medial to the superior turbinate, about 1 cm above the posterior choana

 

This is the correct anatomical description. The sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which lies above and medial to the superior turbinate, and is located ~1 cm above the posterior choana, near the posterior part of the nasal septum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is located in the middle meatus, anterior to the ethmoidal bulla and posterior to the uncinate process: Refers to structures in the middle meatus (like uncinate process and ethmoidal bulla), which are related to drainage of anterior ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary sinuses, not the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option B. It lies within the superior meatus, between the middle turbinate and the roof of the nasal cavity: The superior meatus receives drainage from posterior ethmoid cells, but not the sphenoid sinus. The sphenoid ostium lies above this level.

 

Option D. It is found lateral to the middle turbinate, at the level of the agger nasi cells and frontal recess: Describes the middle meatus region, involving agger nasi and frontal recess, which are not related to sphenoid sinus drainage.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, located medial to the superior turbinate and approximately 1 cm above the posterior choana.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: Surgical section of the vidian nerve via the pterygopalatine fossa
Application of anesthetic to the anterior ethmoidal nerve at the cribriform plate
Resection of infraorbital nerve branches at the nasal vestibule
Local anesthetic pledget placement near the middle turbinate to block sphenopalatine ganglion

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent watery nasal discharge that worsens with temperature changes and exposure to strong smells. He is diagnosed with vasomotor rhinitis that has not responded to antihistamines or intranasal steroids. The ENT surgeon plans a procedure to reduce parasympathetic innervation to the nasal mucosa and control his rhinorrhoea. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical section of the vidian nerve via the pterygopalatine fossa

 

The vidian nerve (nerve of the pterygoid canal) carries parasympathetic fibers (from greater superficial petrosal nerve) and sympathetic fibers (from deep petrosal nerve). Parasympathetic fibers synapse in the sphenopalatine ganglion and supply nasal glands, promoting secretion. Sectioning the vidian nerve surgically reduces nasal secretion, making it a treatment for refractory vasomotor or allergic rhinitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Application of anesthetic to the anterior ethmoidal nerve at the cribriform plate: Incorrect. The anterior ethmoidal nerve is a branch of the nasociliary nerve (V1) and carries general sensory innervation to the anterior-superior nasal cavity. It has no effect on autonomic control of nasal glands.

 

Option C. Resection of infraorbital nerve branches at the nasal vestibule: Incorrect. The infraorbital nerve is a branch of V2 that supplies the vestibule of the nose. It provides somatic sensation, not autonomic control, and resection would not reduce rhinorrhoea.

 

 

Option D. Local anesthetic pledget placement near the middle turbinate to block sphenopalatine ganglion: Incorrect. A pledget near the sphenopalatine foramen can temporarily block sensory and autonomic fibers for procedures or diagnostic blocks but is not a definitive treatment for chronic rhinitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Surgical section of the vidian nerve reduces parasympathetic stimulation to nasal glands and is used to treat refractory vasomotor rhinitis with excessive rhinorrhoea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 138

choices.text: During quiet breathing, most of the air flows through the olfactory region to enhance odor detection
Newborns with choanal atresia can breathe comfortably through the mouth if nasal breathing is blocked
The middle turbinate regulates nasal airflow through cyclical vasodilation and constriction
The anterior end of the inferior turbinate undergoes swelling and shrinkage to regulate airflow through the nasal passages

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nasal respiration and physiology is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The anterior end of the inferior turbinate undergoes swelling and shrinkage to regulate airflow through the nasal passages

 

The anterior end of the inferior turbinate plays a key role in airflow regulation by swelling and shrinking, contributing to the nasal cycle and adjusting airflow resistance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. During quiet breathing, most of the air flows through the olfactory region to enhance odor detection: Incorrect. Only a small portion of inspired air reaches the olfactory region during quiet breathing. Therefore, weak odors must be actively sniffed to reach the olfactory area.

 

Option B. Newborns with choanal atresia can breathe comfortably through the mouth if nasal breathing is blocked: Incorrect. Newborns are obligate nasal breathers, and in cases of bilateral choanal atresia, they may asphyxiate if not urgently treated, as they cannot switch easily to oral breathing.

 

Option C. The middle turbinate regulates nasal airflow through cyclical vasodilation and constriction: Incorrect. It is not the middle turbinate, but the inferior turbinate, particularly its anterior end, that undergoes cyclical swelling and decongestion to help regulate nasal airflow.

 

Educational Objective:


The anterior end of the inferior turbinate undergoes swelling and shrinkage to regulate airflow, playing a key role in the physiological nasal cycle.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 140

choices.text: Reduced vibrissae function leading to allergic sensitization
Loss of nasal humidification impairing ciliary function and increasing airway infection risk
Cooling of inspired air causing bronchial hyperreactivity
Reduced mucus production triggering olfactory nerve dysfunction

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent nasal obstruction due to chronic rhinitis. He reports frequent dryness in his nose and mouth, morning headaches, and excessive daytime sleepiness. Overnight pulse oximetry shows episodic oxygen desaturation and elevated CO₂ levels. Which of the following best explains the physiological consequence of his chronic nasal obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of nasal humidification impairing ciliary function and increasing airway infection risk

 

One of the key functions of the nasal mucosa is to humidify inspired air. The mucosa is lined with mucous and serous glands, and about 1000 mL of water is evaporated per day for this purpose. When nasal breathing is obstructed, dry, unconditioned air enters the lower respiratory tract, impairing ciliary clearance, increasing infection risk, and adversely affecting gas exchange—leading to hypercapnia (↑pCO₂) and hypoxia (↓pO₂), as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced vibrissae function leading to allergic sensitization: Incorrect. While vibrissae help trap large particles, their dysfunction does not directly lead to CO₂ retention or significant respiratory compromise seen in this case.

 

Option C. Cooling of inspired air causing bronchial hyperreactivity: Incorrect. The nasal mucosa actually warms up cold air effectively to body temperature within 0.25 seconds, preventing cooling-related bronchial hyperreactivity. This is not impaired unless there is mucosal damage or obstruction.

 

Option D. Reduced mucus production triggering olfactory nerve dysfunction: Incorrect. While dryness may cause local irritation, olfactory nerve dysfunction is primarily due to damage near the cribriform plate or loss of olfactory neuroepithelium—not due to mucus reduction alone.

 

Educational Objective:


Nasal obstruction impairs humidification, leading to ciliary dysfunction, increased infection risk, and altered gas exchange with elevated pCO₂ and reduced pO₂.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 140

choices.text: Coordinated mucociliary action transporting mucus to the nasopharynx
Passive drainage of secretions via gravity into the oropharynx
Compression of turbinates causing forced air expulsion
Peristaltic movement of nasal blood vessels aiding mucous movement

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms plays the primary role in clearing inhaled pathogens and particles from the nasal cavity to protect the lower respiratory tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coordinated mucociliary action transporting mucus to the nasopharynx

 

The mucociliary clearance mechanism is the most effective and primary defense of the upper airway, especially the nasal cavity, in protecting the lungs. A mucous blanket composed of mucous and serous layers traps pathogens and particles, while cilia beat rhythmically (10–20 times/sec) to move this blanket toward the nasopharynx, from where it is swallowed. This “conveyor belt” moves at 5–10 mm/min, clearing secretions every 10–20 minutes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Passive drainage of secretions via gravity into the oropharynx: Incorrect. While gravity can help drain secretions passively in some positions, it is not the primary mechanism of respiratory defense. Mucociliary transport is far more active and efficient.

 

Option C. Compression of turbinates causing forced air expulsion: Incorrect. Turbinates play a role in increasing surface area for filtration, humidification, and temperature regulation—but they do not compress to expel air. Sneezing, not turbinate compression, is the active expulsive reflex.

 

Option D. Peristaltic movement of nasal blood vessels aiding mucous movement: Incorrect. Peristalsis is not a feature of blood vessels, and blood vessel tone doesn’t move mucus. Vascular changes affect turbinate size and airflow resistance, but do not transport mucus.

 

Educational Objective:


The mucociliary mechanism, driven by ciliary action over a mucus blanket, is the primary defense that clears trapped particles and pathogens from the nasal cavity toward the pharynx.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 141

choices.text: Olfactory receptor cells send their central processes through the cribriform plate to synapse in the olfactory bulb
Ammonia vapors are ideal agents for testing olfactory function due to their strong smell
The olfactory region is located in the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity where most air passes during quiet breathing
The trigeminal nerve transmits conscious perception of smell to the amygdala and prepyriform cortex

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains of diminished ability to smell and taste food during an upper respiratory tract infection. Which of the following statements best describes the physiology of olfaction and its clinical relevance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Olfactory receptor cells send their central processes through the cribriform plate to synapse in the olfactory bulb

 

The central processes of olfactory receptor cells form the olfactory nerves, which pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone and synapse in the mitral cells of the olfactory bulb. From there, impulses are relayed via the olfactory tract to higher centers like the prepyriform cortex and amygdala for conscious perception.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ammonia vapors are ideal agents for testing olfactory function due to their strong smell: Incorrect. Ammonia vapors stimulate the trigeminal nerve endings, not the olfactory nerve. Hence, they are not used to test olfaction, as they cause nasal irritation rather than true olfactory stimulation.

 

Option C. The olfactory region is located in the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity where most air passes during quiet breathing: Incorrect. The olfactory region is located high up in the nasal cavity, not in the inferior meatus. During quiet breathing, minimal air reaches the olfactory area, which is why sniffing is often needed for weak odors.

 

Option D. The trigeminal nerve transmits conscious perception of smell to the amygdala and prepyriform cortex: Incorrect. The trigeminal nerve (CN V) transmits pain, temperature, and irritation, not the sense of smell. Conscious olfaction is mediated by the olfactory nerve and tract, projecting to the amygdala and prepyriform cortex.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Olfactory receptor cells send their central processes through the cribriform plate to synapse in the olfactory bulb, initiating the neural pathway for the sense of smell.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 142

choices.text: Parosmia due to misdirected regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers
Hyposmia caused by persistent mucosal edema post-infection
Psychogenic anosmia due to conversion disorder
Anosmia due to complete destruction of olfactory bulbs

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of altered smell sensation following a recent influenza infection. He describes that previously pleasant odors now seem foul or rotten. He had complete loss of smell for about two weeks, which partially returned. On examination, nasal passages are clear, and there is no obvious obstruction or mucosal swelling. What is the most likely explanation for his symptom?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parosmia due to misdirected regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers

 

The patient describes distorted perception of smell (disgusting or foul odors) during recovery from a prior episode of anosmia, most likely post-influenza. This clinical picture is characteristic of parosmia, which is believed to occur due to misdirected regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers. Intracranial pathology should also be considered and ruled out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyposmia caused by persistent mucosal edema post-infection: Incorrect. Hyposmia refers to partial loss of smell, often caused by nasal obstruction or mucosal edema (e.g., allergic rhinitis, polyps, common cold). However, this patient has no nasal obstruction and his primary complaint is distortion, not reduction, of smell.

 

Option C. Psychogenic anosmia due to conversion disorder: Incorrect. Although psychogenic anosmia is a possibility in rare cases, this patient's history of post-viral anosmia with parosmia during recovery is a classic organic cause. There is no psychological context supporting conversion disorder here.

 

Option D. Anosmia due to complete destruction of olfactory bulbs: Incorrect. Complete destruction of the olfactory bulbs leads to permanent anosmia, not partial or distorted recovery. The fact that the patient has regained some olfactory function argues against this option.

 

Educational Objective:


Parosmia—distortion of smell perception—is commonly seen during recovery from post-viral anosmia and is attributed to misdirected regeneration of olfactory nerve fibers.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 142

choices.text: Damage to sustentacular and Bowman gland cells affecting olfactory sensory neurons
Obstruction of olfactory cleft due to viral mucosal edema in inferior meatus
Primary viral infection of trigeminal sensory neurons causing signal misrouting
Destruction of mitral cells in olfactory bulb by host autoantibodies post-viral clearance

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with sudden onset of loss of smell and taste without nasal congestion or rhinorrhea. He has no prior history of allergies or chronic rhinitis. He tests positive for COVID-19 the next day. According to recent clinical studies on SARS-CoV-2, which of the following best explains the mechanism of anosmia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Damage to sustentacular and Bowman gland cells affecting olfactory sensory neurons

 

Studies suggest that SARS-CoV-2 binds to ACE2 receptors, which are highly expressed on supporting cells like sustentacular and Bowman gland cells in the olfactory epithelium. Damage to these cells leads to indirect dysfunction or death of olfactory sensory neurons (OSNs), causing anosmia. This mechanism explains why anosmia can occur without nasal congestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstruction of olfactory cleft due to viral mucosal edema in inferior meatus: Incorrect. The inferior meatus is not the site of olfactory perception. The olfactory region is high up, and obstruction of the olfactory cleft due to mucosal edema is plausible in rhinitis, but this patient lacks nasal obstruction—supporting a neural/inflammatory rather than mechanical cause.

 

Option C. Primary viral infection of trigeminal sensory neurons causing signal misrouting: Incorrect. The trigeminal nerve is involved in sensing irritants, not smell perception. There is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 directly infects trigeminal neurons in anosmia pathogenesis.

 

Option D. Destruction of mitral cells in olfactory bulb by host autoantibodies post-viral clearance: Incorrect. While olfactory bulb involvement is possible, mitral cells are second-order neurons and not primary targets in early olfactory loss. Also, autoimmune destruction of mitral cells is not a common mechanism in COVID-related anosmia.

 

Educational Objective:


COVID-19-related anosmia is primarily due to SARS-CoV-2-induced damage to sustentacular and Bowman gland cells, which support olfactory sensory neurons in the nasal epithelium.

 

Ref: Patekar S, Bradoo R, Joshi A, Dere R, Kulpe D. Olfactory and Taste Dysfunction in Indian Population with COVID-19: A Study on 300 Patients. Indian J Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2022 Oct;74(Suppl 2):3223-3228.

choices.text: Crooked nose
Hump nose
Saddle nose deformity
Deviated nasal septum

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with a visible depression over the nasal bridge following a history of untreated nasal trauma 2 years ago. He complains of nasal blockage and dissatisfaction with his facial appearance. On examination, there is a midline depression of the nasal dorsum involving both the cartilaginous and bony components. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Saddle nose deformity

 

Characterized by depression of the nasal dorsum, it commonly follows trauma, cartilage destruction (e.g., abscess, TB, syphilis), or excessive septal surgery. The deformity may involve both bony and cartilaginous parts.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crooked nose: Incorrect. A crooked nose has a C- or S-shaped curvature of the nasal dorsum. This patient has a depressed dorsum, not lateral curvature.

 

 

Option B. Hump nose: Incorrect. Hump nose presents with prominence of the dorsum rather than depression. This is the opposite of a saddle nose.

 

Option D. Deviated nasal septum: Incorrect. While this can cause nasal obstruction, it does not present with visible depression of the nasal dorsum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A saddle nose deformity presents as a depressed nasal dorsum due to trauma, septal cartilage loss, or infection, and may involve both bony and cartilaginous structures.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 143

choices.text: Simple dermoid excision through an external approach
Daily cleaning and conservative management
Endoscopic sinus surgery to remove the tract
Combined neurosurgical and otolaryngologic excision with closure of the skull base defect

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a midline nasal pit over the dorsum of the nose, from which a tuft of hair is protruding. MRI reveals a sinus tract passing through the foramen caecum and attached to the dura. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Combined neurosurgical and otolaryngologic excision with closure of the skull base defect

 

This is the definitive treatment for dermoid cysts with intracranial extension.

 

Simple dermoid beneath the skin

 

Dermoid with an external pit or sinus. It lies in front of septum and deep to nasal bones.

 

Dermoid with an intracranial connection to dura.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple dermoid excision through an external approach: Incorrect. as it may not address intracranial extension and risks meningitis or CSF leak.

 

Option B. Daily cleaning and conservative management: Incorrect. as the sinus tract with intracranial extension must be surgically removed to prevent infection.

 

Option C. Endoscopic sinus surgery to remove the trac: Incorrect. this is not the approach of choice for congenital midline dermoid cysts with dural connections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital midline nasal dermoid cysts with intracranial extension require combined ENT and neurosurgical excision with skull base defect closure to prevent meningitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 143

choices.text: Immediate incision and drainage should be performed to relieve pain
Squeezing the lesion can help drain the pus and accelerate healing
Oral antibiotics are unnecessary unless systemic symptoms develop
Manipulation should be avoided due to risk of cavernous sinus thrombosis

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with severe pain and redness over the tip of his nose. He gives a history of plucking nose hair 2 days ago. On examination, there is a tender, red swelling in the nasal vestibule suggestive of a furuncle. Which of the following statements regarding the management is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manipulation should be avoided due to risk of cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

Furuncles of the danger triangle of the face (which includes the nose) should not be manipulated to avoid the life-threatening risk of spread via facial and angular veins to the cavernous sinus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate incision and drainage should be performed to relieve pain: Incorrect. Incision should only be done if there is a clear fluctuant area; otherwise, premature incision increases risk of spreading infection.

 

Option B. Squeezing the lesion can help drain the pus and accelerate healing: Incorrect. Squeezing is contraindicated as it can lead to retrograde spread of infection into the cavernous sinus.

 

Option C. Oral antibiotics are unnecessary unless systemic symptoms develop : Incorrect. Systemic antibiotics (effective against Staph aureus) should be started early to control the infection and prevent complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Furuncles of the nose should not be manipulated due to the risk of retrograde spread of infection causing cavernous sinus thrombosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 145

choices.text: Acute vestibulitis; treat with systemic antifungals
Chronic vestibulitis; apply antibiotic-steroid ointment after cleaning with hydrogen peroxide
Nasal furunculosis; squeeze to release pus and apply antiseptic
Atrophic rhinitis; begin long-term saline nasal irrigation and vitamin A therapy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with redness, tenderness, and crusting around her nasal vestibule. She has a history of chronic nasal discharge due to allergic rhinitis and frequent use of a handkerchief to clean her nose. On examination, the vestibular skin is excoriated and covered with crusts. What is the most likely diagnosis and initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic vestibulitis; apply antibiotic-steroid ointment after cleaning with hydrogen peroxide

 

This is the standard treatment as described: crusts are removed with hydrogen peroxide-soaked applicator, and a topical antibiotic-steroid is applied, continued even after apparent healing to prevent relapse.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute vestibulitis; treat with systemic antifungals: Incorrect. The causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus, not fungi. Treatment requires antibacterial, not antifungal agents.

 

Option C. Nasal furunculosis; squeeze to release pus and apply antiseptic: Incorrect. Squeezing is contraindicated due to risk of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Also, the clinical description is more in favor of vestibulitis than a localized furuncle.

 

Option D. Atrophic rhinitis; begin long-term saline nasal irrigation and vitamin A therapy: Incorrect. Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by foul-smelling crusts and roomy nasal cavities, not tender erythematous vestibular skin with fissures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic vestibulitis presents with vestibular erythema, crusting, and fissures, and is treated by cleaning with hydrogen peroxide and applying antibiotic-steroid ointment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 145
